title: Bilateral Tinnitus and Asymmetric Noise-Induced Hearing Loss in a Shooter
chief_complaint: I have a constant high-pitched ringing in both ears, but over the last 3 months, the ringing in my right ear has suddenly gotten louder with some pressure. I'm having trouble understanding speech in noisy places.

problem_summary.onset: Long-standing tinnitus and hearing loss; sudden exacerbation in the right ear 3 months ago.
problem_summary.course: Chronic with acute change in the right ear.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Aural fullness/head pressure; constant high-pitched tinnitus (worse on right).
problem_summary.functional_impact: Difficulty understanding speech in noise; no perceived difficulty in quiet.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Concerned about recent changes in tinnitus and pressure.

history.present_illness: Patient reports constant bilateral tinnitus (steady, low-level, high-pitched). Sudden change in right ear tinnitus 3 months ago (louder, noticeable for short periods) accompanied by aural/head pressure. Right ear hearing perceived as poorer.
history.noise_exposure_history: Significant history of firearms use without protection as a child. Currently uses protection. Left-handed shooter (consistent with right ear asymmetry).
history.patient_goals: Evaluation of hearing and tinnitus changes.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Slight SNHL 250-2000 Hz, steeply sloping to severe loss 3-8 kHz with a profound notch at 6 kHz. Left ear: Normal sensitivity 250-2000 Hz, steeply sloping to moderately-severe SNHL 3-8 kHz with a recovery at 6 kHz. Asymmetry consistent with acoustic shadow of head for a left-handed shooter.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRT consistent with PTA. Word recognition scores are excellent bilaterally in quiet.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Normal ipsilateral and contralateral thresholds at 500-2000 Hz. Absent at 4000 Hz. Reflex decay negative at 500 and 1000 Hz.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with asymmetric high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss, significantly worse in the right ear, consistent with noise exposure from left-handed firearms use. Speech recognition in quiet is excellent bilaterally. Middle ear function is normal.
counseling_points: Referral to ENT is necessary due to the sudden change in tinnitus, pressure, and asymmetric hearing loss to rule out retrocochlear pathology.
Your hearing loss pattern matches your history of shooting left-handed; the right ear is more exposed to the noise.
Strict use of custom hearing protection is critical to prevent further damage.
We will monitor your hearing annually.
We can discuss assistive listening devices or amplification once medical clearance is obtained.
notes_for_actor: You are a 33-year-old male, likely comfortable with firearms.
You are specifically a left-handed shooter.
You are not struggling in quiet conversations, but noisy restaurants are difficult.
You are concerned about the sudden increase in ringing and pressure in your right ear.
